CABINET.POLICY REGARDING OIL CONCESSIONS IN BRITISH TERRITORY. MEMORANDUM BY THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES. AT the Cabinet meeting held on the 9th October, 1930, consideration was givento a memorandum by the Petroleum Department, Board of Trade, regarding the entry of foreign capital for the development of oil production in British territories,upon which the following conclusion was reached : " (i) To approve in principle the change in policy proposed by the President of the Board of Trade in C.I.D. Paper No. 1017-B, while reserving details until after the matter had been discussed at the Imperial Conference." A Memorandum, the terms of which were agreed between the Departmentsconcerned, was accordingly submitted to the General Economic Committee of theImperial Conference (E (30) 29), but the Summary of Proceedings of the ImperialConference contains no reference to this matter, and it would appear that the general question involved was not discussed by the Economic Committee. The Cabinet at their meeting of the 9th October further concluded " (ii) To take note that the Secretary of State for the Colonies desired to reduce the proposed period of notice of two years before the policy came into effect, at any rate in the case of British Guiana."' As it has not been found possible to induce the British Oil Companies to explorefor oil in British Guiana owing to their disbelief in its existence in commercialquantities, I am now anxious, on grounds of general policy in the Colony, that the embargo on the operation of foreign countries in British Guiana should be removedat once, and accordingly, if my colleagues see no objection, I would propose to informthe Governor to that effect, on the understanding that the latter would not beempowered to make any definitive arrangements with foreign interests without myexpress approval. (Initialled) P. Colonial Office, November 24, 1930.[22071j
